STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 06, 2022
Jennifer Shores
Saginaw County DHHS
P O Box 5070
411 E Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
RE: License #: CP730201395
Saginaw County DHHS
P O Box 5070
411 E Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
Dear Ms. Shores:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
08/25/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 8 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, the agency must identify why the previous CAP
was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395-0920.
Sincerely,
Mark R. Hunter, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 395-2847
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP730201395
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jennifer Shores, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Saginaw County DHHS
Facility Address: P O Box 5070
411 E Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
Facility Telephone #: (989) 758-1100
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1991
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation.
The placement specifications shall include all of the following:
(b) Gender,
(d) Number of children preferred by the family,
Two of the six foster home files reviewed contained an annual evaluation report that
included placement specifications that were different that those identified on the
associated license (3706). An annual report for one home dated 10/04/21
recommended placement of females only and the corresponding license (3706)
identified placement of both male and female (b). An annual report for a second
home dated 07/22/22 recommended a capacity of two and the corresponding 3706
indicated a capacity of four (d).
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(4) Before completion of the written report required by subrule (5
6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster parent with a
verbal summary of the preliminary findings at the conclusion of
the evaluation.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed contained a special evaluation report
that indicated a verbal summary of the preliminary findings had not been provided to
the foster parent. In this instance the foster parent was reported to be uncooperative
with the investigation and the recommendation was to not renew the foster home
license. There were no children placed in the home at the time of the investigation.
The time period of this investigation was 12/08/21.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
4

One of the two special evaluations contained a special evaluation report that
included the last names of children placed in the home. The special evaluation was
dated 03/15/22.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include adequate
documentation to indicate the foster parent was given a copy of the completed report
(a) or that they were informed in writing they could have a written response included
as an attachment to the report (b). The agency typically includes a cover letter that
is sent along with the report that establishes compliance with this rule. It is probable
this was done since the file included a written response by the foster parent,
however, the letter to establish compliance could not be located at the time of this
evaluation. The date of this special investigation was 12/08/21.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
social service worker with children in the home was given a copy of the completed
special evaluation. This was dated 03/15/22. There were no children placed in the
home of the second foster home that had a special evaluation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited 11/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP
Approved 01/13/2022
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child, the
child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency, and the
other parties involved in providing needed services, or medical
care, unless the agency documents why any of the entities have
not been involved.
5

Five of the eight foster child records reviewed indicated at least one time period
where a Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP) for all entities involved was not
completed or could not be located. Four of the five only had one time period each
and the fifth had three time periods.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of the eight foster child records reviewed contained an initial service plan that
was not completed within the time frame required by this rule. In this example the
time period had an ending date of 02/05/2022 and the corresponding initial service
plan was completed 02/15/2022.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
One of the three independent living records reviewed did not include documentation
that the youth had been adequately assessed to determine independent living was
the most appropriate placement for the youth. The youth had an identified date of
placement in independent living of 07/04/2022.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth
is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's housing,
clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is available.
Two of the three independent living records reviewed did not include a budget to
determine adequate financial support as required by this rule. The dates of
placement in independent living for these two youth were 01/19/2022 and
07/04/2022 respectively.
R 400.12511 Independent living contract.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living services
for a youth, the agency shall document all of the following
information in the case record within 30 calendar days of
termination of its services:
(a) The reason for the termination.
(b) The youth’s new location.
6

(c) A summary of the services provided during care and the
needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
The one record for a youth discharged from independent living did not include
documentation on the standard form (69) that the information required by this rule
was documented. The identified date of discharge for this youth was 01/24/2022.
R 400.12511 Independent living contract.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each youth who
ends independent living is provided with all of the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing,
counseling/mental health services, and emergency resources.
(b) A birth certificate.
(c) A social security card.
(d) The youth’s funds and personal property.
The one record for a youth discharged from independent living did not include
documentation on the standard form (69) that the information required by this rule
was documented. The identified date of discharge for this youth was 01/24/2022.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements reviewed.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 801-03 The health screens within the MiSACWIS Health Profile section
must be updated quarterly to ensure the child's current health information is
up-to-date and accurate.
One of the eight foster care youth records reviewed indicated the information in
the medical passport had not been maintained/updated as required. In this
example the most recent signed medical passport by a caregiver was signed
08/31/2021.
FOM 722-6B The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
Two of the eight foster child records reviewed contained at least one FTM that was
either not completed or not documented as required by this policy. The record for
the first youth did not have a documented FTM for the time period 11/25/21 to
02/21/22. The second youth had a reported FTM on 02/28/22 but a DHS-1105
was not located as being completed as required.
7

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
At the time of the exit conference the agency was reminded of the importance of
uploading signed/dated documents as required/applicable.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
None
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the interim evaluation completed
11/29/2021. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of that evaluation were 327
(1)(d), 327 (6)(c), 327 (7), 413 (1)(c)(ii) (f)(i), and 509 (3)(o).
Trends and Repeat Violation Assessment
The only area identified as a repeat violation as a part of this renewal evaluation is
327 (6)(c).
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment included a review of the corrective action plan
that was submitted for the interim evaluation and actions that were implemented to
establish and maintain compliance. It also included a review of the agency’s status
regarding key performance indicators.
Interviews
Child Welfare Staff participated in entrance and exit meetings providing input
regarding agency practices and policies. There were no noted concerns.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
8

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
08/26/2022
________________________________________
Mark R. Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
09/06/2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
